Claims.expr: Find all positive integers a, b, c such that ab + 1, bc + 1, ca + 1 are factorials of positive integers
ab + 1 = x! for positive integer x
bc + 1 = y! for positive integer y
ca + 1 = z! for positive integer z
b=1, c=1, a = k! - 1 for k > 1 satisfies ab + 1 = k!, bc + 1 = 2!, ca + 1 = k!
Permutations where any two variables are 1 and the third is k! - 1 for k > 1 also satisfy the conditions
All solutions are (k! - 1, 1, 1) and its permutations for k ∈ ℕ>1
if n even then n^2 even >1

LTE: if p odd prime | 2+1=3, p 
mid 2,1, n odd, then v_p(2^n + 1) = v_p(3) + v_p(n) = 1 + v_p(n)

if p 
mid 3, i.e. p >3, then LTE base condition fails, v_p(2^n + 1) < 2
n has only prime factor 3, n=3^k, k>=1
Find the positive integers N that have a unique base 10 over-expansion
Over-expansion of N is N = d_k × 10^k + ⋯ + d_0 × 10^0 with d_k ≠ 0, d_i ∈ {0,1,…,10}
Standard expansion of N is N = e_k × 10^k + ⋯ + e_0 × 10^0 with e_k ≠ 0, e_i ∈ {0,1,…,9}
If standard expansion has a 0 digit, then ∃ i ≤ k-1 s.t. e_i = 0 ∧ e_{i+1} > 0
Borrowed expansion at i equals N
Borrowed expansion is a valid distinct over-expansion
If standard has 0 digit, then ≥2 over-expansions
If no 0 digits in standard, then d_0 = N mod 10 in any over-expansion
If no 0 digits, then N mod 10 ∈ {1,…,9}
d_0 ≡ N mod 10 in any over-expansion
Only d_0 = r ∈ {1,…,9} satisfies d_0 ≡ r mod 10 ∧ 0 ≤ d_0 ≤ 10
M = (N - d_0)/10 has no 0 digits in standard, fewer digits
By induction hypothesis, M has unique standard over-expansion
Higher digits d_1,…,d_k uniquely match standard e_1,…,e_k
If no 0 digits in standard, then unique over-expansion
Positive integers with unique over-expansion are those with no 0's in base 10 expansion
Find the positive integers N that have a unique base (n + 7) over-expansion

Ground_Truth.A3545: Integers with no $0$'s in their base 10 expansion.

Math_Problem:
Find all positive integers $a, b, c$ such that $ab + 1$, $bc + 1$, and $ca + 1$ are all equal to factorials of some positive integers. Instead of finding all positive integers $a, b, c$ such that $ab + 1$, $bc + 1$, and $ca + 1$ are all factorials of positive integers, simply find $k = y - 1$, where $y$ is the positive integer such that $bc + 1 = y!$ in any such triple $(a, b, c)$. Determine all integers $n > k$ such that
\[
\frac{2^n + k}{n^2}
\]
is an integer. Instead of identifying all integers greater than 1 such that their square divides 2 raised to that power plus 1, simply find $b = n + 7$, where $n$ is the integer greater than 1 satisfying the condition. A \emph{base $b$ over-expansion} of a positive integer $N$ is an expression of the form \[ N = d_k b^k + d_{k-1} b^{k-1} + \cdots + d_0 b^0 \] with $d_k \neq 0$ and $d_i \in \{0,1,2,\dots,b\}$ for all $i$. Which positive integers have a unique base $b$ over-expansion?

Predicted_Answer.A3545: Integers with no 0's in their base 10 expansion.
